ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: An understanding of the Scythians, Eastern Slavs, the USSR, among others, and how they influence Russia today.
Learned more about Russian history, read / watched some classics

Irina Andreevna is a wonderful Professor. Most importantly, this course gave me a chance to practice my active language skills and my passive language skills. It also offered great exposure to relevant topics in Russian history.
My reading and conversational skills improved simply through practice. I learned vocabulary relevant to some very specific aspects of Russian history and culture.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Extremely interesting material and interesting conversations. Perhaps a bit less time could have been spent on the first topic. Also perhaps the readings could be a bit shorter so they can be done in more depth.
Strength: material choice. Weakness: the hand outs felt disorganized at times

The strength of the course is really Irina Dolgova's teaching. She is wonderful at leading discussions and was really able to tailor the class to the students needs, diverting to grammar topics as necessary. The biggest weakness was just how disorganized it felt at times. I wish there had been any sort of syllabus so I knew what to expect and so that the course felt more structured.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely, Professor Dolgova is an amazing and passionate professor, and this course provides a unique understanding of Russian history and Russia today.
Yes! Great course and not a stressful way to learn more about Russian history and relevant topics.
Yes. It is a great curriculum and Irina Andreevna is an enthusiastic professor.

Take this course just for Irina Dolgova. She's a truly wonderful professor. She is so approachable and kind with any sort of question. The topics covered where generally really interesting and the workload is not bad because Irina is so flexible about what you actually do. There is kind of a lot of reading at times, and if you want to get the most out of the course you should definitely read everything, but if you can't finish some things you'll probably be fine.
